at.translation[0].definitions[0].definit: used to say exactly where something or someone is, or where something happens
at.translation[0].definitions[0].example: Does this train stop at Preston?
I was waiting at the bus stop.
Liz and her friend sat down at a corner table.
We’ll meet at Harry’s  (=at Harry’s house).
I spent an unpleasant hour at the dentist’s.
Dad’s at work  (=in the place where he works).
At the top of the stairs, she paused.
at.translation[0].definitions[1].definit: used to say what event or activity someone is taking part in
at.translation[0].definitions[1].example: I met my wife at a disco.
The matter was discussed at a meeting of the finance committee.
I’m sorry, Pam’s at lunch just now.
at.translation[0].definitions[2].definit: used to say that someone is studying somewhere regularly
at.translation[0].definitions[2].example: Hulme was a student at Oxford in the 1960s.
at.translation[0].definitions[3].definit: used to say exactly when something happens
at.translation[0].definitions[4].definit: during a particular period of time
at.translation[0].definitions[4].example: My husband often works at night.
We go to Midnight Mass at Christmas.
at.translation[0].definitions[5].definit: used to say which thing or person an action is directed towards or intended for
at.translation[0].definitions[5].example: He gazed up at the sky.
You don’t have to shout at me.
The older girls used to throw stones at me.
The course is aimed at those aged 16 or over.
at.translation[0].definitions[6].definit: used to say what or who causes an action or feeling
at.translation[0].definitions[6].example: The children all laughed at his jokes.
Dad got really mad at me for scratching the car.
her distress at having to leave
at.translation[0].definitions[7].definit: used to say which subject or activity you are talking about when you say whether someone is skilful, successful etc or not
at.translation[0].definitions[7].example: Barbara’s getting on really well at her new job.
He’s an expert at making things out of junk.
I’ve always been good at maths.
at.translation[0].definitions[8].definit: used to say that someone or something is in a particular state
at.translation[0].definitions[8].example: Many children are still at risk from neglect or abuse.
at.translation[0].definitions[9].definit: used to show a price, rate, level, age, speed etc
at.translation[0].definitions[9].example: old books selling at 10 cents each
You should have more sense at your age.
The Renault was travelling at about 50 mph.
Amanda rode off at a gallop.
at.translation[0].definitions[10].defini: used to say what someone tries to touch, or keeps touching
at.translation[0].definitions[10].exampl: George was just picking at his food.
Sarah took another sip at her wine.
at.translation[0].definitions[11].defini: used to say what someone tries to do
at.translation[0].definitions[11].exampl: the student’s first attempt at a piece of research
They were so beautiful that I decided to have a go at growing them.
at.translation[0].definitions[12].defini: because of what someone has said
at.translation[0].definitions[12].exampl: Chapman visited Austria at the invitation of his friend, Hugo Meisl.
At my suggestion, Bernard went to see his former teacher.
at.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: USAGE: At, in, on
at.translation[0].note_box[0].items[3].e: – with points of time in the day
at.translation[0].note_box[0].items[4].e: – with holiday periods, meaning the few days around the holiday
at.translation[0].note_box[0].items[8].e: – with months, seasons, years, and centuries
– with words for buildings, for example airport, university, restaurant, art gallery
– with city or place names, when you are talking about stopping during a journey
– with a position or place, when something or someone is inside a larger thing such as a room
– with cities, counties, states, and countries
– with the names of squares, plazas etc
– with a position or place, when one thing is attached to or touching another
You can use either in  or on with street names in British English In American English, use on
